topic: Gender, Social Movements, Poli Particip & Policy

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Prof. Orloff "Gender, Social Movements, Political Participation and Policy" Fall 2016
In this class, we will investigate how gender - as a set of relations, identities and cultural schemas - shapes politics, including political participation and representation, the formation of social movements (e.g., the feminist and anti-ERA movements), and social policy, as well as how, in turn, political institutions and policy shape gender. We aim to understand gendered politics and policy from both "top down" and "bottom up" perspectives. And we will take advantage of the fact that we are in the middle of a Presidential election to examine gendered politics in the contemporary United States.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The class will be a mix of lectures and discussion.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Exams, short final paper, class participation.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
This is a tentative list of books; please confirm before purchase.

Dorothy Sue Cobble, Linda Gordon and Astrid Henry, Feminism Unfinished: A Short, Surprising History of American Women's Movements (Liveright, 2014).
ISBN-13: 978-1631490545

R.W. Connell, Masculinities (Berkeley: University of California Press, second edition, 2005).
ISBN-13: 978-0520246980

We will also read several articles; these readings will be available online on Canvas.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: As a supplemental (not required) text for those who would like some background in gender studies, Raewyn Connell's Gender in World Perspective (second edition) Malden, MA: Polity, 2009) is a good, short introduction. ISBN-13: 9780745645674
